e_text:
Scope 3 emissions are the result of activities from assets not owned or controlled by ADM, but that indirectly affect our value chain. Scope 3 emissions include all sources not within ADM’s scope 1 and 2 boundary.

The Greenhouse Gas Protocol defines 15 categories of scope 3 emissions, though not every category is relevant to ADM. In fact, there are three key categories that ADM can control and have the largest impact. You’ll learn more in this lesson.
e_subtitle: Select each category to learn more. When you’re done exploring all categories, the Next button will appear. Select it to continue.

popup.e_text: All items or services purchased by ADM including raw material inputs, chemicals, packaging, office supplies, tech support, etc.
Any equipment or large purchases paid for through capital expenditures rather than operating budgets.
Emissions related to the creation of fuels we use onsite, such as the drilling and refining of petroleum.
Transportation of our raw ingredients/commodities, as well as the transportation of our finished products, if we pay for the transportation.
Emissions from the decomposition/landfilling of waste generated in ADM operations.
Emissions from vehicles used to transport employees for business trips, such as airplanes or rental cars.
Emissions from the personal vehicles or public transportation vehicles of employees traveling to and from work.

These are emissions from assets owned by another company and operated by the reporting entity. Because ADM reports using an operational control methodology, upstream leased asset emissions do not apply to ADM because these emissions are already reported in our Scope 1 footprint.
Transportation of ADM’s final product to customers, except where we pay for the transportation, which is covered by Category 4 (Upstream transportation & distribution).
Emissions from processing of sold intermediate products by third parties (e.g., manufacturers) after sale by ADM.
Emissions from the use of products we sell, such as the combustion of ethanol or biodiesel.
Emissions from the disposal of products ADM sold, typically the emissions from packaging waste.
ADM-owned facilities or vehicles that are leased to and operated by another entity.
This category is not applicable to ADM. An example is a local McDonald’s that is not owned or operated by McDonald’s corporation.
Emissions from companies that ADM invests in. For example, as a 27% owner of Wilmar, we report 27% of Wilmar’s scope 1+2 footprint in our scope 3 Investments category.
